channel.title: Paradox - Infinite Loop or Never Happen?
channel.description:
I'm going to quickly explain a paradox scenario:
(This all theoretical and doesnt express my true viewpoints)
I want to go back in time to stop David Cameron becoming Prime Minister so i do this and kill him so he never becomes the prime minister, now my future self (which is the present now) never experiences David Cameron becoming Prime Minister so he never has to travel back in time to stop this which then results in David Cameron not being killed and the loop continues.
My question is, would that loop continue endlessly or is there an alternate solution?

item.title: Paradox - Infinite Loop or Never Happen?
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

Bowser jr:

Jc: It doesn’t disprove timetravel. It shows that time travel and linear time doesn’t go together.

I was referring to what Barjavel was trying to prove, although everyone is entitled to their own interpretation of the paradox.

Read full topic
item.source: Paradox - Infinite Loop or Never Happen?

item.source: Paradox - Infinite Loop or Never Happen?

item.title: Paradox - Infinite Loop or Never Happen?
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“MacaYork, post:3, topic:509507”]ok thanks,
what other types of paradoxes are there if you dont mind explaining :)[/quote]
There are four categories of paradoxes, though only three are really mentioned. The three are veridical paradoxes, falsidical paradoxes, and antinomical paradoxes (antinomies).

[quote=“Davidi2, post:5, topic:509507”][quote author=asshole_rule link=topic=627751.msg4266165#msg4266165 date=1364074923]
the dumb thread paradox, where users keep posting dumb threads, it’s never ending.
[/quote]that would be an infinite loop though, not a paradox[/quote]
Haha, touche.

MacaYork:

With regards to your first point what if you could only travel to points in time where time travel exists so therefore we havent discovered it?

Barjavel came up with this paradox in order to construe the impossibility of time travel.

Anyways, paradoxes are great to think about, and if you want to read up on them, I recommend some of Godel’s work. I’ve actually started reading Godel, Escher, Bach by Hofstadter and he brushes upon a paradox or two, so I’d recommend that as well. I mean, you could always just read Hofstadter for fun, he’s quite amazing.

I don’t think there’s much more to discuss, as paradoxes are usually either true, false, or contradictory within themselves. Bowser jr has already stated that the paradox proves the impossibility of time travel, but if you feel as if this should be unlocked, feel free to PM me with a reason.

Read full topic
item.source: Paradox - Infinite Loop or Never Happen?

item.title: Paradox - Infinite Loop or Never Happen?
item.dc:creator: @Flame3 John
item.description:
@Flame3 wrote:

The name for that sort of paradox is the grandfather paradox, and it cannot truely be discussed as the entire concept is in theory, and we would only end up repeating a reworded version of the paradox.

Read full topic
